lines.text: It's a country station, rather off the beaten track.
Oh, I don't mind, as long as it's near the railway.

[pocket watch to ear, it having been flattened by a train, exclaims in surprise]
It's stopped!
Albert. Who's Albert?
He comes in for me when I'm not here.
Well, which is his clock?

[Jerry puts William's clock on the mantelpiece]
He hasn't got a clock. He's still alive.

[snatching clock]
Hey, give me that back!
What? Aren't you go to put it with the others?
What, amongst them? They're a lot of tombstones!
[William Porter is wheel-tapping a train]
You may think me a little stupid but why do they tap them?
Well, you see madam, it's like this. If I tap the wheel with this hammer and the wheel goes clang, then I know that the wheel's there.
But supposing that the wheel doesn't go clang?
Well, then I know that the train's gone!
You're wasting your time.
Well, what are you doing?
Just watching you wasting your time.
Next train's gone!

[confronting the station master about a cancelled train]
I've got a return to Dublin.
And I've got a single to Belfast.
And what am I going to do with my Cork.
[Opens his mouth to reply but thinks better of it and says nothing]
Well, I can't give you the exact number at the moment.

[pauses to think]
But in rough figures I would say quite a lot.

[sniffs]
Is something burning somewhere?
That would be Albert, cooking the breakfast.
Smells more like somebody cooking Albert.
Got yer clock?

[going into danger, reassuringly]
I'm behind yer.
Do you want to go in front?
No, I can see all right from here.

[wanting to know if he can let a train through]
Can I stick me signals up?
Yes, if it'll give you any pleasure.
Ther's a place in Ireland called Buggleskelly.
That's nothing, there's a place in Wales called Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch.
You should have come sooner!
I couldn't, my wife's had quinsy...
Like that woman in Canada?
Everything on this station is either too old or doesn't work. And you're both!
